key_points: Actor Alec Baldwin fatally shot a cinematographer with a prop gun on set in New Mexico on Oct 21, 2021.
The incident underscores the commonplace nature of guns in Hollywood films.
Research indicates that the presence of guns in movies is linked to an increased risk of shootings, both on and off the set.
Gun violence in PG-13 movies has nearly tripled from 1985 to 2015, with similar trends in TV dramas.
The gun industry collaborates with filmmakers for product placement, benefiting from increased sales.
Seeing guns in movies can amplify viewer aggression through the 'weapons effect' and desensitize them to violence.
The depiction of guns in movies influences children, making them more likely to imitate violent behavior.
A study showed children who watched movie clips with guns were more likely to handle and pull the trigger of a real, disabled gun.
Movies often portray gun use as justified for self-protection, potentially encouraging such thinking in viewers.
The heavy depiction of guns by Hollywood may contribute to the United States' high rate of gun ownership and associated violence.
